div.head: Aim
div.p: The present edition aims at improving the text of the Chronicon by Romualdus Salernitanus (Romualdus II Guarna) through a new collation of the text of the print editions by Garufi 1914 and Bonetti 2001 against A and O, the main witnesses of the 'short version' of the work.

div.head: The Chronicon
div.p: The Chronicon is a universal history composed by Archbishop of Salerno Romualdus II Guarna shortly before his death (1181). For the period going from Adam until 1125, Romualdus compiled previous sources, possibly working on a previous compilation (see paragraph 'Authenticity' below), while for contemporary events his work is a primary source. In particular, Romualdus was one of the protagonists of the "Peace of Venice" (1177), a treaty between Emperor Frederick I, Pope Alexander III and other political entities of the Italian area, covered in great detail in the last part of the Chronicon. In fact, Romualdus was a leading figure of the delegation sent by King William II of Sicily to the negotiations in Venice.

div.head: Structure of the work
div.p: The Chronicon initially follows ancient Jewish, Greek and and Roman ancient history, then European (continental and Byzantine) events. It then includes a digression on the the story of the Lombards and the Franks until Louis the Pious, from paragraph g108.24-109.5 i.e. page 108 of Garufi's edition, line 24, to par. g159.9-159.25. From this point on, the scope of the narrative returns to be wide, continental, but it progressively focusses on Southern Italy, until it substantially becomes a chronicle of its Norman conquest and then of the Kingdom of Sicily, ending with the detailed account of the Peace of Venice (from par. v-b298a of the present edition to the end of the work).

div.head: Sources
div.p: Garufi 1914 (henceforth "Garufi") has a very informative separate apparatus of footnotes providing the sources of each passage of the work. Detailed information and critical discussion on the sources of Romualdus and his relationship with Norman historiography are in Arndt 1966 (running footnotes); Garufi, XXV-XXVIII (introduction); Hoffmann 1967, 165-170; Matthew 1981, 243-249; 258-267; Zabbia 2002; Zabbia 2004, 380-382 and 392-394; Zabbia 2010, 22 and 25-60.

list.item: The question of his sources for the Norman period (roughly after 999) is intertwined with the authorship issue, on which see next paragraph and the bibliography cited above, but a key source for this period are the Annales by Lupus Protospatharius.

div.head: Authorship: textual evidence
Authorship: hypotheses
div.p: For Matthew 1981, the first note only proves that the scribe who wrote it believed in Romualdus' authorship, and the second that the report of the Peace of Venice was based on the archbishop's, possibly written, testimony. Mattews discusses numerous arguments in favor of the thesis that the author of the Chronicon is not Romualdus: he suggests that around 1126 an anonymous compiler based in the Apulian city of Troia wrote a compilation of universal history reporting events until 1125 (see Matthew 1981, 239-256); later, "a writer from Salerno decided to set down the events of the reigns to Roger II and the two Williams in 1177", while only the report of the Peace of Venice "is taken from the written, eitiwness, and true account of Archbishop Romuald" (Matthew 1981, 269-270). Vitolo 2007, 549-551 follows Matthew, and stresses the lack of attention to the famous medicine school of Salerno (except for a short note in g189.2-189.5). Oldoni (2001 and 2004) suggest that the text until year 893 may have been written by Romualdus; the section on years 893-1127 shows "una scrittura a più mani ove intervengono, con Romualdo, almeno altri due scribi"; years 1127-1173 were entrusted to Romualdus' collaborators; finally, only the section after 1173 was "forse [l]'unica parte certamente originale dell'opera sua".

Zabbia 2004 confuted Mattew's arguments and suggested that Romualdus is the author of the whole work, though he did not rule out the possibility, based on the first note mentioned above ("Ab hoc loco adiunctum est...', par. g213.1-213.8), that the archbishop continued a previously existing universal chronicon. In his view, the note "Ab hoc loco..." simply suggests that "sino al 1125 l'arcivescono avrebbe condotto il suo lavoro sulle fonti; dopo quella data – a partire cioè da quando Romualdo aveva all'incirca quindici anni – il racconto sarebbe fondato sulla memoria dell'autore" (also see Pio 1996, 26 n. 26), though he adds: "Tutto ciò non consente di escludere che l'arcivescono potesse disporre di una cronaca in cui almeno parte del materiale fosse già organizzata" (Zabbia 2004, 389 and 392, where he writes of a "codice miscellaneo"). In a later essay (Zabbia 2010), the same scholar proposed a theory closer to one of Matthew's: that for the period between 999 (the arrival of Normans to Southern Italy) to 1125, the source of Romualdus was a pre-existing short chronicle, written in Salerno within the first fourth of the XII century. For Zabbia, this short chronical was the common source of Romualdus' Chronicon for this period and of the Chronicon Amalphitanum (Zabbia 2010, 25-42), but comparison between the two works shows that Romualdus did not copy his source, but integrated it with other information, for example regarding the papacy. See Zabbia 2004, 384 and Zabbia 2010, 21-24 for further bibliography on the authorship issue.

The hypothesis proposed by Zabbia 2010 essay is economic and entirely consistent with this evidence. If Romualdus mixed and summarized different sources (directly or supervising the work of his collaborators) for the universal history until 999, and mostly followed and integrated the short chronicle postulated by Zabbia until 1125, then a scribe could reasonably write in the note in g213.1-213.8 that only from that point on ("ab hoc loco") Romualdus added up new information to the Chronicon.

div.head: Manuscripts
div.p:
Another important witness is
O: a fragment of MS Ottobonianus Latinus 2940, (XIV century), folios 16r-18v, available in
https://digi.vatlib.it/mss/detail/Ott.lat.2940; III manifest in
https://digi.vatlib.it/iiif/MSS_Ott.lat.2940/manifest.json.

The importance of O lies in the fact that, as argued by Schwartz 1978, 139 n. 119, it might have been copied from a lost MS, older than A. Also see Matthews 1981, 250 n. 1; Zabbia 2004, 387, endnotes 26, 27 and 29; Zabbia 2006, 62.

The siglum used by Garufi, Schwartz and other scholars for this manuscript is 'Aa'. I am modifying it to 'O' for consistency with the other sigla (one letter only, not including character 'A' already used for Vat. Lat. 3973), thus facilitating the processing of XML files.

div.head: Print editions and translations
div.p: The two most recent print editions of the Chronicon are Garufi (for which see the review in Erdmann 1930) and Bonetti 2001 (henceforth "Bonetti"). The latter starts with paragraph g163.6-163.7 and includes and Italian translation.
Bonetti uses Garufi as "testo base" and Arndt 1866 as "elemento integrativo" (see 'Nota al testo', Bonetti, 56).

Previously, the work had been published by Muratori 1725; Del Re 1875 (from g212.1-212.4, with Italian translation); Arndt 1866 (from g163.11-164.9). Schmale 1986, 308-371 published the Peace of Venice, based on Garufi's text, with a German translation. Carucci 1996 is an Italian translation of select passages of the Chronicon about the Peace of Venice. Loud 2012, 250-268 provides an English translation of the narrative of years 1125-1154. See Garufi, XXVIII-XXXI for previous print editions, and http://www.geschichtsquellen.de/werk/4214 for other translations and general bibliography.
Bibliographical details on the editions by Bonetti and Garufi are in the 'sourceDesc' element of this TEI XML file; on the other works cited, in the bibliography at the end of this introduction.

div.head: Paragraph identifiers
div.p: Paragraphs ('p' elements in the TEI XML source) have been labelled with @xml:id attributes based on Garufi. For instance, paragraph 'g163.1-163.5' goes from page 163, line 1 to page 163, line 5 of the Garufi edition. In some cases, Garufi's paragraphs have been further broken into smaller 'p' elements to facilitate collation.

div.head: Sigla
div.p: As noted in the 'sourceDesc' element, in the @wit attributes of 'lem' and 'rdg' elements I used abbreviations 'g' for Garufi, 'b' for Bonetti, 'a' for MS A (first hand), 'a2' for the second hand of MS A (probably XVII century) and 'o' for the fragment of MS O.

div.head: Long and short versions of the work
div.p: Scholars are unanimously convinced that these are later additions to the 'short' version' (see Garufi, XXXIV; Matthew 1981, 241-243, Zabbia 2004, 386-387; Zabbia 2006, 59-61 and Zabbia 2010, 24-25, 27 and 43-49), but Garufi himself includes some of them in his text. He therefore considers these ones Romualdus' own additions (followed by Palumbo 1978, 76-78), and Zabbia 2006, 60 suggests that the first ones (g3.7-3.16, g10.n2-10.n5, g30.n1-30.n3) might actually be lacunae in A, rather than additions in B and C. Zabbia maintains that those additions are generally consistent with the style of the whole Chronicon, that they have been written shortly after the composition of the whole work (Zabbia 2004, 397: "interventi databili a ridosso della stesura"), that it is not impossible that Romualdus himself (Zabbia 2006, 60) or "uno dei suoi collaboratori (Zabbia 2010, 25) added them to the Chronicon.

div.head: Second hand in A
div.p: Someone, probably in the XVII century, copied most of the parts missing in MS A (the 'long version additions', plus some missing quires or folios) into the marginal space of the manuscript, drawing them from MS B (see Matthew 1981, 242). In addition to the 'long version additions' mentioned in the previous paragraph, I transcribed and collated also the following portions of MS A added by the second hand and marked their readings with siglum 'a2' in 'app' elements: g180.10-180.12, g180.13-180.15, g181.1-181.1, g181.2-181.5, g181.6-181.10, g181.10-181.11, g181.12-182.19, g183.1-184.6, g184.7-184.9, g184.10-184.13.

div.head: Portions of the work included in fragment O
Paragraphs missing in A and O (no variants)
div.p: Some paragraphs are missing both in MS A (first or second hand) and in MS O. For them I am simply reporting the text of Garufi or Bonetti (i.e. Garufi/Arndt), without any 'app' elements. These paragraphs are: g74.21-74.21, g85.20-85.30, g85.31-86.12, g86.13-86.25, g86.26-87.29, g87.30-88.28, .29-90.15, g90.16-90.20, g90.21-92.5, g92.6-92.7, g92.8-92.9, g179.10-179.11, 6.10-186.11, g187.3-187.4, g199.13-199.15, g206.n4-206.n5, g215.n14-216.n10.

div.head: Collation exemplars
div.p: Garufi was the collation exemplar for the first part of the work, from the incipit through paragraph g163.1-163.5.

Bonetti was the collation exemplar for the part of the text it includes, i.e. from paragraph g163.6-163.7 to the end of the text. The legibility of the print in Bonetti's edition is better than in Garufi's, so it lends itself to less error-prone OCR: this is the reason why I decided to use Bonetti as collation exemplar for this part of the work.

In the part of the text collated against Bonetti (g163.1-163.5 to the end), whenever I chose the reading of a MS against that of Bonetti, and the text of Garufi diverged from that fo Bonetti, I recorded both Garufi's and Bonetti's readings in the 'app' element.

div.head: Parts for collation
Transpositions
div.p: In part 2-bravo, the order of the paragraphs diverges between Garufi, Bonetti and MS A, do to a number of large transpositions of those paragraphs in the manuscripts. I chose the order of Bonetti.

div.head: GitHub
div.p: The source code of this edition, including transcriptions of the witnesses and Python software, is in the project GitHub repository https://github.com/paolomonella/romualdus.

div.head: Transcription layers
div.p: I transcribed all witnesses at the 'alphabetic layer', but I provided a sample 'graphematic layer' transcription of the first paragraphs of MSS A, B and C, available in the edition GitHub repository. See Monella 2018 (DOI: 10.6092/issn.2532-8816/7286) for a definition of those layers of representation of the text in primary sources. For paragraphs from g116.6-118.8 through g163.1-163.5 I only transcribed major variants.

div.head: Normalization
Variant types and subtypes
div.p: I added a @type attribute to all 'app' elements, and a @subtype attribute to some. Custom Python scripts proposed the values of those attributes, then I reviewed them all manually.

div.head: List of variant types
div.p:
Attribute @type of 'app' can take one of the following values:
'substantive'
'orthographic'
'punctuation'
'gap-in-ms'
'illegible-in-ms'
'transposition'

div.head: Variant subtypes
Variants for which many subtypes apply
div.p: For some variants (i.e. for some 'app' elements), it is impossible to determine one subtype, either because two subtypes apply (e.g., for Symmachus/Simachus 'y' and 'double') or because there are three readings with different types and/or subtypes (e.g. Pisa, Bonetti / Pysas, MS A / Pisas, MS O: Pisa/Pysas is ubstantive' variant, but Pysas/Pisas is an 'orthographic'/'y' variant). I took a pragmatic (and certainly debatable) approach to this issue, as I chose what I thought was the most relevant type/subtype: for example, I chose subtype 'y' for Symmachus/Simachus and type 'substantive' for Pisa/Pysas/Pisas.

div.head: Distinction between substantive and orthographic
div.p: Also, the line between 'substantive' and 'orthographic' variants is thin. This is particularly evident for proper nouns, for which the change of one letter can be considered meaningful. This is why for proper nouns I tended to choose @type='substantive', except for the most common orthographic subtypes, such as 'double' (Callixtus/Calixtus), 'y' (Babyloniam/Babiloniam) or 'h' (Hieronymo/Ieronimo).

div.head: Case variants
div.p: Some 'app' elements mark a distinction between the lowercase and capitalized spelling of the same word: these elements have @type="orthographic" with @subtype="case". For example, 'Cainan' (my lemma) vs cainan (reading of Garufi and of MS A). MSS will always have the lowercase spelling by convention, because capitalization does not have graphematic value in them. Those 'app' elements mean that I capitalize a word that was in lowercase in the print edition, or vice versa.

div.head: Punctuation variants
div.p: The case of punctuation is similar to the preceding one. I chose not to transcribe the MSS punctuation, so all 'app' elements with type="punctuation" mean that I am modifying the punctuation of the print edition (of the collation exemplar for that part of the text). For example, I deleted all quotation marks from the Bonetti edition, but sometimes punctuation modification implies significant differences in phrase and sentence segmentation, therefore in syntax and text interpretation.

div.head: Orthography variants
Factual variants
div.p: The aim of this edition is to publish a text as close as possible to what has been written by Romualdus or his collaborators, not to what has actually happened in history, so I did not correct fact, names or dates. Besides, such a task would have required a historic competence that is beyond my skills. The footnotes in the Garufi edition and the essays cited in this introduction provide rich critical discussions on this matter.

Dates in particular are an aspect in which the Chronicon is often imprecise and there is great variability among the witnesses: when dates in A or O diverged from those in Garufi and Bonetti, I systematically adhered to the print editions.

div.head: The text before and after the author
div.p: In some passages Romualdus follows a source very closely, but skips some words. Garufi sometimes integrates the missing words. For instance, in g100.6-103.2 the Chronicon copies Paul the Deacon Hist. 14.116 "adest Geisericus cum ualidissimo suae gentis exercitu", but skips the words "suae gentis", which are found in no MS of the Chronicon. In these cases I reject Garufi's integrations based on the principle of considering the Chronicon an autonomous text, rather than a copy of his sources.

These cases, together with comples philological issues such as the attitions differentiating the 'long' and 'short' version of the Chronicon, raise interesting, very general questions on the work of the philologist. Paul the Deacon's text is 'before' Romualdus and his (possible) collaborators, while that of the additions may be 'after' him (or them). Where is the 'original text' that the philologist approximates?
The 'original text', especially in cases of a complex editorial work such as the Chronicon, looks as elusive as the elusive notion of 'present', at the sliding edge between past and future.

These issues become more evident to us as we get closer to the author. Mordenti 2001, par. 9.1 discusses the extreme case of transcription and raises "[la] domanda fondamentale della filologia [...] quella che riguarda il concetto di testo e, in particolare, di testo originale" and quotes D'Arco Silvio Avalle and Cesare Segre: "Il concetto di originale, nel senso di testo autentico esprimente la volontà dell'autore, è uno dei più sfuggenti ed ambigui della critica del testo. [...] le singole opere di uno scrittore costituiscono a rigore una sezione a volte casuale e provvisoria – e non sempre operata dall'autore stesso [...] di quel flusso continuo di adattamenti e di spostamenti successivi attraverso cui si esprimono le tendenze fondamentali di un sistema letterario" (Avalle 1972, 32-33); and "Ogni testo scritto è in realtà trascritto: da un copista, da un tipografo. Anche l'autografo è una trascrizione (dalla brutta copia); e la brutta copia costituisce di norma un testo non definitivo. Insomma, ogni trascrizione è anteriore o posteriore al testo; nessun testo può essere identificato col Testo" Segre 1979, 36.
